data.author: Nobull
data.content: Could not post this on ADVFN as sometimes I get the "contact support message if the problem persists" My  takeaways on yesterday’s presentation to private investors  (not perfect, I cannot remember everything so help from others would be appreciated) are: Operating margin matters, and our directors will make sure it is maintained (although it is complex what with changes in mix of sales causing switches, say, to lower value products, etc.) but they point out there are product engineering solutions to deal with margin preservation, and their "partners" value what McBride do.  There are now quarterly review procedures on contracts to amend them (by mutual consent?) to take account of cost headwinds.  Partners have differing requirements all the time: one minute it is more perfume additives, another it is packaging changes, etc. and it just happens that cost-outs are flavour of the month for now. Debt paydown is no longer such a pressing priority, so similar falls of £26.3m to that in the period just reported on will, in the current accounting period, be a bit unlikely to be repeated: they are looking for growth investment opportunities with a payback period of 2 years or less (sounds shareholder value accretive to me).  Our CFO comes from a private equity background, which to me seems important in making the right acquisitions.  Buying existing businesses is maybe less risky than building a whole new factory from scratch, I wonder? The risk of hackers disrupting our business, the way M&S has suffered, is being managed appropriately. Chris Smith outlined a strategy they are concentrating on.  I could go into detail but it is maybe unwise to if the company doesn't publish yesterday's chat. The company has not built up a maintenance capex backlog in paying down debt as quickly as it has.  They said it was difficult to separate growth and maintenance capex because replacing a machine with a new one often involved a bit of both. Liquids are expensive to transport, so the factories that make these need to be close to where their partners are.  It is different with dishwasher tablets, etc. Contract manufacturing for the branders is important: it covers the (fixed cost?) overheads. The remaining £45m of Transformation benefits still to come will be weighted to the 2028 accounting period (£20m in that one).  The rest will come in the other accounting periods before then, £5m in the current one. The accordion facility will help finance acquisitions, I wonder? The company is quite different from before: the new operating model seems to be responsible for a change in the previous falling sales trend and the “operating margins all over the place” problem.  CS believes the business is much more stable now, and the top line is more stable now.  The new operating model seems to have many advantages over the one before.  JMV.  Open to correction on anything, if I have got it wrong.

data.author: Kingfisher68
data.content: We held this share for a while and sold earlier this year (missing the move upwards). Tempted to get back in at today's share price. Clearly the market doesn't like the flat-lining top line (sales up less than 1% on a constant currency basis 2024-2025). But: 1. Good cash flow generation. Net debt down £26m over the past 12 months, so presumably net debt could be paid down to zero in 4 years if management prioritised this (over dividends, capex, M&A etc). 2. Net debt of £105m isn't ridiculous when adjusted EBITDA is £87m. 3. PE ratio of 5.5x seems like bargain basement. 4. Ditto EV:EBITDA around 3.6x. Not much else in the sector available at these multiples. 5. Pension deficit seems manageable. 6. Clear transformation of this company over the past few years. 7. Possible recommencement of dividends in the near future (though we'd rather net debt was paid down). 8. Contract manufacturing growth strong. Should help admittedly low net profit margin. We're tempted to buy this one and file it away in the proverbial locked drawer. Bank future modest dividends and watch on as EBITDA nudges up to £100m in 3-5 years and net debt declines steadily. Should be a rerating of multiples at some point and maybe a 2x. Thoughts? Are we missing something?

data.author: Nobull
data.content: For some reason I could not post this on ADVFN - it keeps saying "Contact Support" when I click "post reply". Re #1692, a case of MCP, margin compression paranoia. On a flat run rate of 21p eps, the company should be able to pay off £30m of debt each year and still keep the company the same size (i.e. keep capex equal to depreciation charge), where £30m of debt pay down adds, say, 18p per share p.a. assuming enterprise value remains about the same.  The lower debt servicing costs will help keep eps the same while revenue drops a bit due to supermarkets demanding cost-outs. With an earnings yield of 18% in prospect at the current share price, what is not to like about that? Buffet probably only does about 20% consistently year in year out. Okay, so the two Pauls (Hill and Scott of Vox Markets) don't like anything with operating margins less than 30%, ROCEs less than 30% and FCF growth rates in excess of 30% p.a. so they are never going to like MCB, but if MCB can compound earnings at 18%, I will not grumble. As to complaining about the high price to book, the author maybe does not get it that when you nearly wipe out almost all the equity and then have a strong eps recovery that the price to book rises a lot initially (mega share price rise to reflect sudden return to profitability while net assets remain low): a few more years of 21p eps will soon see the price to book come down as equity replaces the debt component of EV to give a more 'attractive' price to book, an 'attractive' price to book when you have missed out on the massive share price rise.

data.author: tenobas
data.content: congratulations mallard on a truly comprehensive analysis. i am concerned that we are not able to see the wood for the trees. the issue here is that we have a business on a p/e of 5.4 which has barriers to entry and which is stable albeit operating  on a margin of only 3%. the macro economic threat is often mentioned but i think this is a red herring because economic pressures will stimulate economy brand sales. over the last eight years growth has been almost exactly the same as inflation. any switch to dosage packaging has not improved margins. there are however other prospects: 1) ultimately the pension scheme will end as will top-ups (£4m) and actuarial losses (£4m). over eight years there has been no improvement here; the deficit remains the same ~£30m. there is an additional threat here from virgin media versus ntl which will impact 2016 obligations of £150m. there is no estimate of this so say 5%? whilst the pension situation is at best unchanged the turnover is up by a third. 2) the debt shows no obvious trend at around £130m. the outstanding position here is that in y/e 2022 there was a massive hit to profits because the energy crisis was not covered by provisions to increase prices. long term finance costs of about £6m shot up to around £20m. the problem looking forward is that finance costs will be impacted by rising interest rates. (interest rate increases hit highly geared businesses such as this.) overall the finance situation is positive because expectations are worse than the likely worst outcome. 3) y/e 2024 showed a massive rise in gross profit which had been steady at around £240m but which shot up to £347.9m. the probable main cause of this was that energy costs fell back again not offset by contract prices. on the other hand the 2024 report was very bullish in its prospects and this indicates that there is also a long term improvement. the november trading update had y/e 2025 expectations of adjusted operating profit down by 7.4m presumably it is possible to predict the figure so accurately because all contracts run six months in advance. this would suggest an earnings figure of £25m giving a forward p/e of 7.2. so the 2024 jump in profits of £21m might be say: £10 energy cost fallback + £7m finance improvement + £4m operational growth. overall this is positive. the question remains: why is such a good business so cheap? why is the share price falling? what are the possible threats? the risks and uncertainties listed in the annual report look pretty bull****ty to me! do you have any other ideas?

data.author: Nobull
data.content: Sparks, a short and very readable book on the attractions of different business models is The Intelligent Quality Growth Investor 2025 Edition by Long Equity (an attention-grabbing nom de plume, if ever there was one).  It may sharpen up what you want to hear in a presentation, and then maybe such presentations will be less of a drag – I don’t know. The only problem with the book in recommending stocks with persistently high ROCEs (a sign of efficient capital allocation), persistently high operating margins (a sign of pricing power), persistently high FCF growth (a business model that allows growth without requiring huge capex to grow) is that shares in such companies are likely to be priced accordingly so no point in buying them.  The answer maybe is to buy them at a time of crisis but that will be hard to do because the newspaper headlines will be warning about the end of the world, the problem of doing the opposite of what the herd are doing, and then there is the problem of having the cash pile just at the right time to exploit the situation to your advantage.  Still the book is worth reading.  Hope this helps.

data.author: Nobull
data.content: Could not post this on ADVFN as sometimes I get the "contact support message if the problem persists" My  takeaways on yesterday’s presentation to private investors  (not perfect, I cannot remember everything so help from others would be appreciated) are: Operating margin matters, and our directors will make sure it is maintained (although it is complex what with changes in mix of sales causing switches, say, to lower value products, etc.) but they point out there are product engineering solutions to deal with margin preservation, and their "partners" value what McBride do.  There are now quarterly review procedures on contracts to amend them (by mutual consent?) to take account of cost headwinds.  Partners have differing requirements all the time: one minute it is more perfume additives, another it is packaging changes, etc. and it just happens that cost-outs are flavour of the month for now. Debt paydown is no longer such a pressing priority, so similar falls of £26.3m to that in the period just reported on will, in the current accounting period, be a bit unlikely to be repeated: they are looking for growth investment opportunities with a payback period of 2 years or less (sounds shareholder value accretive to me).  Our CFO comes from a private equity background, which to me seems important in making the right acquisitions.  Buying existing businesses is maybe less risky than building a whole new factory from scratch, I wonder? The risk of hackers disrupting our business, the way M&S has suffered, is being managed appropriately. Chris Smith outlined a strategy they are concentrating on.  I could go into detail but it is maybe unwise to if the company doesn't publish yesterday's chat. The company has not built up a maintenance capex backlog in paying down debt as quickly as it has.  They said it was difficult to separate growth and maintenance capex because replacing a machine with a new one often involved a bit of both. Liquids are expensive to transport, so the factories that make these need to be close to where their partners are.  It is different with dishwasher tablets, etc. Contract manufacturing for the branders is important: it covers the (fixed cost?) overheads. The remaining £45m of Transformation benefits still to come will be weighted to the 2028 accounting period (£20m in that one).  The rest will come in the other accounting periods before then, £5m in the current one. The accordion facility will help finance acquisitions, I wonder? The company is quite different from before: the new operating model seems to be responsible for a change in the previous falling sales trend and the “operating margins all over the place” problem.  CS believes the business is much more stable now, and the top line is more stable now.  The new operating model seems to have many advantages over the one before.  JMV.  Open to correction on anything, if I have got it wrong.

data.content: For some reason I could not post this on ADVFN - it keeps saying "Contact Support" when I click "post reply". Re #1692, a case of MCP, margin compression paranoia. On a flat run rate of 21p eps, the company should be able to pay off £30m of debt each year and still keep the company the same size (i.e. keep capex equal to depreciation charge), where £30m of debt pay down adds, say, 18p per share p.a. assuming enterprise value remains about the same.  The lower debt servicing costs will help keep eps the same while revenue drops a bit due to supermarkets demanding cost-outs. With an earnings yield of 18% in prospect at the current share price, what is not to like about that? Buffet probably only does about 20% consistently year in year out. Okay, so the two Pauls (Hill and Scott of Vox Markets) don't like anything with operating margins less than 30%, ROCEs less than 30% and FCF growth rates in excess of 30% p.a. so they are never going to like MCB, but if MCB can compound earnings at 18%, I will not grumble. As to complaining about the high price to book, the author maybe does not get it that when you nearly wipe out almost all the equity and then have a strong eps recovery that the price to book rises a lot initially (mega share price rise to reflect sudden return to profitability while net assets remain low): a few more years of 21p eps will soon see the price to book come down as equity replaces the debt component of EV to give a more 'attractive' price to book, an 'attractive' price to book when you have missed out on the massive share price rise.

data.author: tenobas
data.content: congratulations mallard on a truly comprehensive analysis. i am concerned that we are not able to see the wood for the trees. the issue here is that we have a business on a p/e of 5.4 which has barriers to entry and which is stable albeit operating  on a margin of only 3%. the macro economic threat is often mentioned but i think this is a red herring because economic pressures will stimulate economy brand sales. over the last eight years growth has been almost exactly the same as inflation. any switch to dosage packaging has not improved margins. there are however other prospects: 1) ultimately the pension scheme will end as will top-ups (£4m) and actuarial losses (£4m). over eight years there has been no improvement here; the deficit remains the same ~£30m. there is an additional threat here from virgin media versus ntl which will impact 2016 obligations of £150m. there is no estimate of this so say 5%? whilst the pension situation is at best unchanged the turnover is up by a third. 2) the debt shows no obvious trend at around £130m. the outstanding position here is that in y/e 2022 there was a massive hit to profits because the energy crisis was not covered by provisions to increase prices. long term finance costs of about £6m shot up to around £20m. the problem looking forward is that finance costs will be impacted by rising interest rates. (interest rate increases hit highly geared businesses such as this.) overall the finance situation is positive because expectations are worse than the likely worst outcome. 3) y/e 2024 showed a massive rise in gross profit which had been steady at around £240m but which shot up to £347.9m. the probable main cause of this was that energy costs fell back again not offset by contract prices. on the other hand the 2024 report was very bullish in its prospects and this indicates that there is also a long term improvement. the november trading update had y/e 2025 expectations of adjusted operating profit down by 7.4m presumably it is possible to predict the figure so accurately because all contracts run six months in advance. this would suggest an earnings figure of £25m giving a forward p/e of 7.2. so the 2024 jump in profits of £21m might be say: £10 energy cost fallback + £7m finance improvement + £4m operational growth. overall this is positive. the question remains: why is such a good business so cheap? why is the share price falling? what are the possible threats? the risks and uncertainties listed in the annual report look pretty bull****ty to me! do you have any other ideas?

data.content: Yes, I still I have Mobico.  The covenant gearing (ratio of Net debt to EBITDA?) on MCG is 3x but is expected to drop to 2.5x by year end (receipt of NASB sale proceeds after H1 end). I don't know what the outcome will be on MCG - I suppose if I am honest it could go either way. Hence we believe that as confidence in the sustainability of McBride’s profits grows, its shares will re-rate significantly.

data.author: Nobull
data.content: Sparks, a short and very readable book on the attractions of different business models is The Intelligent Quality Growth Investor 2025 Edition by Long Equity (an attention-grabbing nom de plume, if ever there was one).  It may sharpen up what you want to hear in a presentation, and then maybe such presentations will be less of a drag – I don’t know. The only problem with the book in recommending stocks with persistently high ROCEs (a sign of efficient capital allocation), persistently high operating margins (a sign of pricing power), persistently high FCF growth (a business model that allows growth without requiring huge capex to grow) is that shares in such companies are likely to be priced accordingly so no point in buying them.  The answer maybe is to buy them at a time of crisis but that will be hard to do because the newspaper headlines will be warning about the end of the world, the problem of doing the opposite of what the herd are doing, and then there is the problem of having the cash pile just at the right time to exploit the situation to your advantage.  Still the book is worth reading.  Hope this helps.
